title: 13. Women
description: The legal status, social roles, and limited public visibility of women in classical Athens.

questions.question: How were women regarded in Athenian law?
options: As legal minors with limited rights
As full legal equals to men
As dependent citizens with voting rights

questions.question: What political rights did Athenian women possess?
Why is evidence for women’s lives in Athens limited?
options: Women were poorly educated and left little writing

questions.question: What does Pericles say about women in his Funeral Oration?
options: Their greatest glory was not to be spoken of

questions.question: Why was Pericles’ citizenship law of 451 BCE significant for women?
options: It increased their importance as mothers of citizens
It allowed women to hold office

questions.question: Why was producing children especially important in Athens?
options: High infant mortality required high birth rates

questions.question: In which area of Athenian life did women have a prominent public role?
Which festival was restricted to women and associated with fertility?
Which goddesses were honoured at the Thesmophoria?
What activity did women undertake during the Thesmophoria festival?
options: Camping together for several days near the Pnyx

questions.question: What type of evidence has provided limited insight into women’s lives?
Which genre offers insight into gender relations in Athens?
What theme does Euripides’ Hippolytus explore?
options: The destructive power of love and rejection of marriage

questions.question: What role does Phaedra play in Hippolytus?
options: She falsely accuses Hippolytus after despair

questions.question: How does Aristophanes’ Thesmophoriazusae portray women?
options: As capable of collective organisation and criticism

questions.question: What limitation affects our interpretation of dramatic evidence?
options: All roles were performed by men for male audiences
